May it please yo
r

e

r

re
to yo

r

ch
I could not write w
th
c
r
tainty, nor specify so much as came after to my knoledge,
for where I writt but of 3 of theyr cornet
, that were
defeated, they are found to be six: The first was
e
Cornet of
e
Dukes
gard: of w
ch
e
Captain Pedro de Nicelli
is tak
e

e comp
ie
of

basterd brother to
e

prisonner w
th
his cornet & cullors. The 3 of
Jeronimo
Caraffa
, who had
e compa
ie
of
e marques of Guasto, his
Lieutenant il
Conte Decio de Manfredi

his cornet w
th
his cullo
rs

Biasio
Capozucchi
broth
r
to
Cosimo

e 5 was
Pradiglia
an old
spanish Captaine who was brought into
Arnham
prisoner but
died
e same day of his wound
. the 6 of
Antonio d'Aguay
who had a spanish company of harqubuziers. There were
also taken prisoners
Captaine Jacomo
, heertofore a Captain
of footemen but now in
e Dukes entertaynment. Likewise,
Cap
t
Galeazzo del pozzo
sometyme cornet of Appio Conte
& now entertayned by Jeronimo Caraffa. These are
e
chief of those
t

r

& gentlemen
of quality
prisoners. The nomb
r
of th
e
all I cannot
certify precisely, but as farr as I can learne, they
are toward
a 100, & 240 horses. Theyr horses were
no better then o
rs
, but theyr horsmen far better armed, &
moste of th
e
old & very tall soudiers, the flowre as is
thought of all his horsmen. They receaved no great hurt
in conflict w
th
e footmen, but when they came in sight of
theyr pikes they made a suddain halt, having had before o
r
horse in chase, & beyng come
e point to do execution,
And then o
r
horsmen had
e leasure to recover them selves,
& to charge
e ennemy a freshe, w
ch
put th
e
p
nt
ly in route

Belgia: 1591: July:
This was don
e 14 day, &
e morning after
e ennemyes camp
was full of fires, w
ch
was taken for a token of theyr
suddayn de
tre. many upon yt were sent abrode, both
horse & foote, pesant
& others to learne what was ment
& certaine trompetters were dispatched w
th
counterfayt
erandes to aske after prisoners: But by
e ennemyes
foresighte, all
e advenues of his camp, w
ch
were
very few, were diligently garded, & all comers in so
streightly detayned,
t
wee conteinued alwaies doutfull,
wheth
r
his fires were but stratagemes, to bring us onward,
or that his meaning were otherwise directly to bee gon. Nevertheles
e next day, after there were that sent us word from
neutrall places, that for certain his forces were in transporting
to
Nieumeg
h
side, wherupon there were 3000 footemen &
400 horse sent thitherward, who approched so neer to
e
ennemeyes camp, as they forced a
Corps de garde
w
th
in
theyr trenches, & mighte easily discern,
t
they had
divers of theyr footmen in order of battaile, by
e water side.
O
r
troupes remained there for
e space of 2 houres together
but
ceaving that
e ennemy was unwilling to come to blowes
& finding no security in assualting theyr trenches, being also
uncertain, how many of his camp were passed
e river, they
returned homeward
that night, Howbeit this morning wee
had a letter sent hether from out of
e sconce, wherby wee
were assured, that
e greatest
te of his troupes were
alredy gon over. Again th
r
uppon we sent thether
e
like forces, as the daie before, but found no ennemy when
they came. For all theyr campe was lodged in sight on
e
other side of
e Wael, what they purpose to do next, wee
can not yet conjecture, it is sayd by o
r
prisoners, &
wee have yt oth
r
wise by oth
r
intelligence, that they go
undoutedly for france. But yet we are
swaded that untell
e Duke be assured, what way wilbee taken by
e Germaine
levy, hee will keep in these quarters, yesterday there came
Verdugo
unto him, w
th
all his forces of
Friseland,
but
whether
his mutins of
Diest
&
Herentals
have receaved contentme
nt we
knowe not. The whole assembly of
e g
na
l states
is newly come hether from
e
Hagh:
but I do
not yet
